prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for going on vacation? Coworkers state I am.
So I am child free so I am able to travel and I work 2 jobs so that I can travel. My coworkers are all parents/single parents and are struggling to make ends meet. 

This coworker came up to me and called an asshole because I was taking 2 weeks off to go to Florida. I have relocated from Florida to New England about 2 years ago. I haven’t seen my parents since I moved. They won’t come up to visit and they are having health issues. Granted I don’t need to take two weeks off but I have the time saved up so I might as well. 

Apparently I am leaving the team short staffed. Again not my problem. That is something that management has to handle and I have been planning this for about 4 months. Everyone has been ganging up on me about me leaving. My manager has approved it so she has no issues with it.

One person has told me that they have to miss a recital for their kid. I told the coworker off stating that her kid will have hundreds of recitals and her father can go in your place. 

TDLR; I’m going away for 2 weeks for a vacation and leaving my team short staffed. AITA?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking if the person who posted the situation is in the wrong. Let me read through the details again carefully.

So, the person is child-free and works two jobs to afford traveling. They're going on a two-week vacation to Florida because they haven't seen their parents since moving two years ago. Their parents are in Florida and have health issues, so they're going to visit them. Their coworkers are parents who are struggling financially and have criticized them for taking time off, saying it's leaving the team short-staffed. The manager approved the vacation, but coworkers are upset. One coworker's kid is missing a recital, and the author told them their partner could go instead.

Hmm. The key points here are about work responsibilities, personal time, and the reactions of coworkers. The author has a manager who approved the leave, which suggests that management is okay with it. The coworker's issue is about being short-staffed, but it's management's responsibility to handle staffing, not the employee's. Also, the author is using their saved time off, which they've planned for four months. 

The author is criticized for taking two weeks, but they explain that they have the time saved and it's a combination of vacation and visiting parents. The coworkers are in different situations—parents with financial struggles. However, the author's reasons are personal and valid. The author's response about the recital might have been harsh, but the coworker's problem is about work coverage, not the author's personal time directly affecting them. 

So, the main issue is whether taking the vacation is wrong despite management approval. Since the manager approved it, the author isn't in the wrong for following company policy. The coworkers are upset but their issues are their own struggles. The author isn't responsible for the team's staffing issues; that's management's job. Therefore, the answer is probably B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
